text: A bit of a hectic market today. I want to talk through a couple of broader concepts on what I saw going on today to share with you all. And then I want to take a look specifically at a handful of questions I got on GameStop. As I'm always happy to look and share what I can see with you all. So what happened today? A couple things. The major thing I noticed was this broad rotation in movement of capital because if we take a look across the primary indices, the SPX literally gaped down. That's not crazy, but it's not common. If you go back through this chart and you look for periods where this is over the last six months where it actually gaped down like this, it's not super frequent that it makes those kinds of movements. The SPX spy, whichever you want to use, it tends to be a little slower than that. So we were at a just crazy high level. I wouldn't start freaking out when you see something come off a high and go into a consolidation. That's a very normal behavior. I feel like sometimes people get so used to things kind of going this parabolic up that we forget that there are other directions. So that's one thing I saw. The other thing I saw was when I look across technology using the NASDAQ as a proxy, it took way more of the front. And that's probably because tech

If you look at GameStop, it didn't gap down. It's essentially just an inside candle here relative to the previous day. So on a relative basis, this is actually showing strength, which is hilarious because how often would you consider finding strength in GameStop compared to the SP 500, which today technically it was? But these are very active. The 30s still have 77,580 OI with 48,000 transacted today. That's a really, really busy, really busy strike with 7,000 OI added net over yesterday. So these are getting very active. Lots of interest in them. So the facility is up in these without a doubt, 212. It's anomalous in general compared to normal products, I should say. But for this so far, it's not crazy. We see the puts going off the shelf as they always do. This is very normal. And this doesn't surprise me. It's grossly outrunning the calls though. When we were seeing a lot more of that bullish vol skew to the calls, the calls literally were outpacing the puts. But that's not what we're seeing now. So the market is not heavily pricing in vol on the call side. It is pricing in vol heavily on the put side. So the last thing I want to talk about was another question I got about these spreads. So people were talking about, hey, there was a bunch of puts that traded yesterday. And there was. But these were seemingly part of spreads. So that matters because it exhibits a little bit less conviction than had they been single trades. The whole point of trading verticals is to decrease the sensitivity of the position. And the positions that I saw got put on were really interesting. It looked like a mix of 40s, 45s and 50s. They help us identify things. So for example, I can see 15 of the 40 puts came through at the mid. And then I can see 15 of the 45 puts came through at the bid at the same exact time at the same exact size. That again, tells me that these two are overwhelmingly likely tied to one another. And it looks like a 40, 45 put spread. You don't trade something at this size by happenstance, by just slinging something. So there's an idea here, but we just can't really fully look into it. So we have a couple days left into expiration and we are eagerly waiting to see what's going on here. Overall, it looks like the options positioning is standard, I would say. Meaning I'm not seeing a bunch of super crazy volatility, but I'm also not seeing any. I'm not seeing crazy skew just yet. So this looks like a little bit of a let's see how it goes scenarios. So as always, if you have any questions or anything you want me to take a look at, let me know, be an outlier. See you guys later.
